item.title: Reeves Defends Economic Choices, Touting UK Spending Plans
item.description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves will defend her fiscal choices and trumpet billions of pounds of infrastructure investment in the UK spending review on Wednesday, as Keir Starmer’s government seeks to regain momentum after a faltering first year in power.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes

item.title: Musk Says He Regrets Social Media Posts Lashing Out at Trump
item.description: Elon Musk, who served as a close adviser and confidante to President Donald Trump until a bitter public falling out last week in a series of social-media posts, issued his strongest sign of contrition yet over how he handled the rupture.
item.dc:creator: William Selway

media:content.media:description: Trump and Musk at the White House in March.

item.title: Philippine Trial of VP Sara Duterte Thrown Into Doubt by Senate
item.description: The planned trial of Philippine Vice President Sara Duterte is in doubt after the articles of impeachment were unexpectedly sent by senators back to the House of Representatives, whose prosecutors said they can’t — for now — comply with the request.
item.dc:creator: Cliff Harvey Venzon, Ditas B Lopez

media:content.media:description: Sara Duterte Photographer: Charles M. Vella/SOPA Images/LightRocket/Getty Images

item.title: EIB to Partner With Deutsche Bank to Boost Defense Funding
item.description: The European Union’s lending arm will partner with large European lenders including Deutsche Bank AG to provide €3 billion ($3.4 billion) in funding for defense, overcoming reluctance in the sector to participate in the region’s rearmament.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Andrea Palasciano

media:content.media:description: Artillery shell production in France.

item.title: US, China Officials Agree on Plan That Awaits Xi, Trump Sign-Off
item.description: The US and China capped two days of high-stakes trade talks with a plan to revive the flow of sensitive goods — a framework now awaiting the blessing of Donald Trump and Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Annmarie Hordern

item.title: Erdogan Says Indonesia to Buy Nearly 50 Fighter Jets from Turkey
item.description: Turkey will sell 48 fighter jets to Indonesia in the coming decade, according to President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, as Ankara pushes to build its defense industry and increase exports of military hardware.
item.dc:creator: Firat Kozok, Selcan Hacaoglu

media:content.media:description: ANKARA, TURKIYE- MAY 1: Presentation ceremony of the National Combat Aircraft KAAN on May 1, 2023 in Ankara, Türkiye. According to the President's statements, the National Combat Aircraft (MMU) or TF-X "Kaan" project, which will enter the inventory of the Turkish Armed Forces, is considered an important step in Turkey's aviation and defense industry. (Photo by Yavuz Ozden/ dia images via Getty Images)

item.title: Trump Seeks Quick Path to Supreme Court in Hush Money Appeal
item.description: Donald Trump’s lawyers will be back in court Wednesday to renew their push to dismiss the New York jury verdict that makes him the only person convicted of a felony to serve as president.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Hurtado, David Voreacos, Anika Arora Seth

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump, center, at Manhattan criminal court in New York, in May 2024. Photographer: Steven Hirsch/New York Post/Bloomberg

item.title: Former Top Starmer Aide Sue Gray to Join Advisory Firm Consello
item.description: Keir Starmer’s former chief of staff, Sue Gray, will join global advisory firm Consello Group as its UK chair, moving into business 8 months after her departure from the prime minister’s top team.
item.dc:creator: Ailbhe Rea

media:content.media:description: Sue Gray Photographer: Charles McQuillan/Getty Image

item.title: Trump’s LA Crackdown Risks Global Fallout
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Kate Sullivan

media:content.media:description: A protester taunts a line of California National Guard protecting a federal building in downtown Los Angeles on June 9. Photographer: Eric Thayer/FR171986 AP

item.title: Poland’s Tusk Flags Cabinet Reshuffle Before Confidence Vote
item.description: Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk said he’d reshuffle his government in July, defending his record in power as he sought to rally his ruling coalition ahead of a confidence vote in parliament.
item.dc:creator: Agnieszka Barteczko

media:content.media:description: Donald Tusk speaks in the parliament in Warsaw, on June 11.

item.title: China Urges US to Comply With ‘Hard-Won’ Deal After London Talks
item.description: China cheered a new framework to defuse trade tensions with the US after two days of intense negotiation, calling on both countries to adhere to the agreement and maintain dialogue to stabilize ties.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy

media:content.media:description: He Lifeng departs following trade talks at Lancaster House in London, on June 10. Photographer: Chris J. Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: EU Hones In on Flexible Rules to Fill Gas Storage Before Winter
item.description: The European Union is close to agreeing on more flexibility to achieve gas storage targets ahead of winter following fears that the current goal has contributed to market speculation.
item.dc:creator: John Ainger, Ewa Krukowska

media:content.media:description: Pipes and gas storage tanks at a storage and distribution facility at the port of Barcelona. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg

item.title: Swiss Senate Eases Arms Export Rules Amid Industry Struggles
item.description: Switzerland’s senate approved proposals to loosen strict controls on exports of war materials, a move that could help its increasingly isolated defense industry.
item.dc:creator: Levin Stamm

media:content.media:description: Display models of Swiss P rifle ammunition.

item.title: Mexico’s Pledge to Give Deportees Jobs Hits Snag Over US Flights
item.description: Mexico’s government has pledged to provide jobs for citizens deported from the US, but recent data shows that barely 4% of the tens of thousands expelled since late January have been matched with employment.
item.dc:creator: Amy Stillman, Maya Averbuch

media:content.media:description: Migrants at the Mexican refugee commission, following the suspension of CBP One appointments, in Tapachula, Mexico, on Jan. 27.

item.title: Russia Makes Iran Nuclear Offer for US Pact, Interfax Says
item.description: Russia proposed transferring Iran’s excess nuclear material to its territory as part of efforts to assist Iran and the US in reaching an agreement over the Islamic Republic’s atomic program, Interfax reported.
item.dc:creator: Henry Meyer

media:content.media:description: Iranian Isfahan Uranium Conversion Facilities.

item.title: Chinese Stocks Advance as Preliminary Trade Deal Eases Tensions
item.description: Chinese stocks rose on Wednesday, after the world’s two largest economies agreed on a plan to reduce trade tensions following a two-day meeting in London.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Lin Zhu, Winnie Hsu

media:content.media:description: The Shanghai Financial Exchange Square, which houses the Shanghai Stock Exchange, China Financial Futures Exchange and the offices of the China Securities Depository and Clearing Corp., in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, June 5, 2025. Transactions in China's long-term sovereign bond futures are cooling as traders hold off making bets in the market given continued tariff disputes with the US. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: North Korea Appears to Have Added to Its Nuclear Complex
item.description: North Korea appears to have constructed a new building within its main nuclear complex, satellite imagery showed, in what could be an additional enrichment facility to ramp up the country’s ability to produce nuclear weapons.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Photo by Kim Jae-Hwan/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images) Photographer: SOPA Images/SOPA Images

item.title: EU Sees US Trade Talks Extending Beyond Trump’s July Deadline
item.description: The European Union believes trade negotiations with the US could extend beyond President Donald Trump’s July 9 deadline, even as the speed of the talks has increased over the past week.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: The Port of Barcelona. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg

item.title: Swedish Support for Joining Euro Fades as Krona Strengthens
item.description: Swedes’ enthusiasm to adopt the euro fell for the first time in four and a half years after a recent run of strength for the krona, a survey showed.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Duxbury

media:content.media:description: Stores in Gothenburg, Sweden. Photographer: Fredrik Lerneryd/Bloomberg

item.title: US Assails Sanctions by UK, Allies on Top Israeli Officials
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio rebuked five allies over sanctions they imposed on two members of Israel’s cabinet as fissures between the US and its partners widen over the war in Gaza and the treatment of Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Chua

media:content.media:description: Marco Rubio, US secretary of state, during a meeting with US President Donald Trump and Friedrich Merz, Germany's chancellor, not pictured, in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, June 5, 2025. Relations between Washington and Berlin are tense amid issues ranging from trade imbalances to support for Kyiv.

item.title: India, US to Expedite Trade Talks Ahead of Trump’s Tariff Deadline
item.description: India and the US will expedite trade talks to conclude an agreement that includes “early wins” for both sides, an official said, as the two nations race to clinch a deal before Washington’s tit-for-tat tariffs kick in next month.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava

media:content.media:description: Shipping containers at the Jawaharlal Nehru Port in Navi Mumbai, India.

item.title: EU Ready for Second Attempt at Australia Trade Deal, Envoy Says
item.description: The European Union is ready and willing to make a second attempt at securing a free trade deal with Australia, EU Ambassador Gabriele Visentin said, while adding that the main obstacles to an accord that were identified in 2023 are largely unchanged.
item.dc:creator: Ben Westcott

item.title: Being a Bully on Trade Won’t Work Longer Term, Lagarde Warns
item.description: There’s no longer-term advantage to being a bully on global commerce, according to European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Schneeweiss

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde on June 5.

item.title: Pentagon Slashes in Half Its Request for Air Force F-35s
item.description: The Air Force has cut in half its request to Congress for its signature F-35s, dealing a blow to Lockheed Martin Corp., the top US defense contractor.
item.dc:creator: Roxana Tiron, Anthony Capaccio

media:content.media:description: A US Air Force F35A fighter jet. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

item.title: Downtown LA Under Curfew as Newsom Warns of Trump Overreach
item.description: California Governor Gavin Newsom accused President Donald Trump of misusing his power by mobilizing troops in Los Angeles and warned other states to prepare for similar unrest, as protests over immigration raids stretched into a fifth night and led to a curfew in parts of the city’s downtown.
item.dc:creator: Eliyahu Kamisher

media:content.media:description: Police enforce a curfew in Los Angeles on June 10. Photographer: Mario Tama/Getty Images

item.title: Kirchner’s Ban From Office Marks New Chapter for Argentina
item.description: Argentina’s top court sidelined former President Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner from elections, likely ushering in a new political era in South America’s second biggest economy.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

media:content.media:description: Former Argentine President Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner Photographer: Tomas Cuesta/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Malaysia’s Anwar Faces More Challenges Even as Lawsuit Paused
item.description: After more than two years of relative political stability in Malaysia, Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim faces multiple hurdles that could fuel discontent within his ruling coalition.
item.dc:creator: Anisah Shukry

media:content.media:description: Anwar Ibrahim

item.title: Trump Poised to Repeal Biden Curbs on Power Plant Pollution
item.description: The Trump administration will propose scrapping Biden-era climate mandates requiring the nation’s power plants to curb planet-warming greenhouse gas emissions as soon as Wednesday, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter, Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: Steam rises from a power plant in Adamsville, Alabama.

item.title: National Guard Providing Security for ICE Officers, US Says
item.description: National Guard troops are now protecting Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers in and around Los Angeles, marking an expansion of their duties since being deployed by President Donald Trump this week.
item.dc:creator: Isabela Fleischmann

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA - JUNE 10: Protesters gather in front of California National Guard soldiers and LAPD officers guarding the Edward R. Roybal Federal building as protests continue in Los Angeles following four days of clashes with police after a series of immigration raids on June 10, 2025 in Los Angeles, California. Tensions in the city remain high after the Trump administration called in the National Guard against the wishes of city leaders. (Photo by Mario Tama/Getty Images)

item.title: Trump Tariffs Can Stay in Effect Longer, Appeals Court Says
item.description: Donald Trump can continue to enforce his global tariffs for now, a federal appeals court held in a win for the president on one of his signature economic policies.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Tillman, Erik Larson

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump Photographer: Ken Cedeno/UPI
